channel.title: Hellpp... How do I make a Java program execute
channel.description:
How do I make a program that, when a certain button is clicked, (the button in my interface that I made is named jStartServ) will open an external program, or, in other words, how do I get one of my buttons on my interface to run a batch file, or any other file.
Any suggestions or a straight answer is greatly appreciated! Couldn't find any Java tutorials on neither Google, Youtube nor here.

item.title: Hellpp... How do I make a Java program execute
item.dc:creator: @Coelho Coelho
item.description:
@Coelho wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:7, topic:401596”][quote author=Coelho link=topic=498657.msg3646552#msg3646552 date=1309424088]

You could check the operating system of the host computer running the application using System.getProperty(“os.name”)

Runtime.getRuntime().exec("java some.package.stuff.Main");

The above would work on any operating system that has Java (except Windows 7 x64).
EDIT: No it should work on ANY operating system.

As long as “java” is set in the path; which is something a lot of people in this community have a problem doing. And also, we don’t know what “external command” he’s talking about. It could be Windows-specific.

True we don’t know what hes talking about. But also, java does not have to be set in the path for that to work. I realized that a long time ago while I was testing with it. As long as its sandboxed inside java it magically knows the classpath. Crazy right?
[/quote]

If a program isn’t in the path, then the computer won’t know where to find it. This is why you get “‘java’ is not recognized as an internal or external program.”

With Macs, it’s set in the path by default; in linux, installing the java package sets the path as well. Windows doesn’t do that.[/quote]
But I was stating using Runtime.getRuntime().exec(""); automatically (for whatever reason) knows the Java classpath without it being set. Try it yourself.

Read full topic
item.source: Hellpp... How do I make a Java program execute

item.title: Hellpp... How do I make a Java program execute
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Coelho, post:6, topic:401596”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=498657.msg3646540#msg3646540 date=1309423411]

You could check the operating system of the host computer running the application using System.getProperty(“os.name”)

Runtime.getRuntime().exec("java some.package.stuff.Main");

The above would work on any operating system that has Java (except Windows 7 x64).
EDIT: No it should work on ANY operating system.

As long as “java” is set in the path; which is something a lot of people in this community have a problem doing. And also, we don’t know what “external command” he’s talking about. It could be Windows-specific.
[/quote]
True we don’t know what hes talking about. But also, java does not have to be set in the path for that to work. I realized that a long time ago while I was testing with it. As long as its sandboxed inside java it magically knows the classpath. Crazy right?[/quote]

If a program isn’t in the path, then the computer won’t know where to find it. This is why you get “‘java’ is not recognized as an internal or external program.”

With Macs, it’s set in the path by default; in linux, installing the java package sets the path as well. Windows doesn’t do that.

item.source: Hellpp... How do I make a Java program execute

item.title: Hellpp... How do I make a Java program execute
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Coelho, post:2, topic:401596”] Process process = Runtime.getRuntime().exec("Batch code here");
To execute a program in java. Also, be wary of that doing this you might break Java’s multiplatform ability (not sure, but I think batch code in Runtime.getRuntime().exec dosen’t work on every OS). If your not asking for this, you need to explain yourself better.[/quote]

Yes it would break the “independence” of Java. What Runtime.getRuntime().exec() does can be thought of as opening the shell (the CMD prompt on windows, or Terminal on Linux/Mac) and executing the String.

For example, doing

Runtime.getRuntime().exec("start restart.bat");

would work for a windows machine, but since Linux doesn’t have a “start” command, it would result in an exception being thrown (hopefully). If it was altered so that the OS would know what to do with the command (let’s say, Linux had the command “start”), it still wouldn’t know what to do with the bat file, because linux doesn’t natively support batch files. I mean, you could probably download a program that parses the batch code, and executes the contents correctly (ie. changing “copy” to “cp”). But that also results in a problem since most people here use absolute paths. So the following code wouldn’t execute cross-platform

"C:\Program Files\Java\jre6\bin\java.exe" SomeClass

first of all because linux doesn’t use the letter naming for drives.

If however, you made a link to a file called “java.exe” in the specified directory, it wouldn’t run the program because it doesn’t know how to execute exe files. (unless it was built with Mono, in which case, you’d still have to do “mono java.exe”)

In general, it’s not considered a good idea to do things like this.

Read full topic
item.source: Hellpp... How do I make a Java program execute

item.title: Hellpp... How do I make a Java program execute
item.dc:creator: @Coelho Coelho
item.description:
@Coelho wrote:

Process process = Runtime.getRuntime().exec("Batch code here");

To execute a program in java. Also, be wary of that doing this you might break Java’s multiplatform ability (not sure, but I think batch code in Runtime.getRuntime().exec dosen’t work on every OS). If your not asking for this, you need to explain yourself better.

Read full topic
